bibl.title: Newspaper clipping, The News, Washington (D.C.), January 6, 1903

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The News, Washington (D.C.), January 6, 1903
div1.p:
SENATOR MARTIN WISHES PEN-
SION FOR SURGEON'S WIDOW.

Has Bill For That Purpose In Con-
gress And Will Do His Best
To Have It Passed.

Washington, Jan. 6.--Senator Martin of
Virginia will, at an early date, urge con-
sideration of a bill which he introduced
in the upper branch of Congress yester-
day providing for a pension of $333 per
month for Mrs. Emilie Lawrence Reed,
widow of the late Dr. Walter Reed,
whose researches in connection with the
propagation of yellow fever germs has
saved more lives than were lost in the
recent Spanish-American War, accord-
ing to a recent opinion of Gen. Leonard
Wood.

The bill introduced by Senator Martin
was referred to the Committee on Pen-
sions.

“Dr. Reed deserves well, not only of
his country, but of humanity, and it is
mete that those he left dependent upon
him should receive some measure of the
debt which this country owes him,” said
the Senator.
